Posts.Content: Jan 19, 2011 02:29AM pennylane wrote: It was a joy to read her descriptions of her summer cottage, her cats, her love of snow...a truly deep, thoughtful artist...she will so be missed...My deepest sympathies to her husband, friends, and family............
Posts.Title: Bopeep is an angel Leah_S

Posts.Content: Jun 14, 2008 11:19AM pennylane wrote: cupcake, I'm so sorry this is happening to you.  The beginning is such a brutal and lonely feeling of freefall.  The only thing I could hang onto was the words of other women who had been there and were able to tell me by example that it does get so much better.  I was diagnosed in the summer of 2005 and was the biggest baby, yet here I am, quite alright and here to tell you, you will be too!  Please keep coming here and don't ever be afraid to ask us for emotional support.  It is an honor to help you get through this.  There is also a very good breast cancer support group called, Y-Me.  I mention them because they have a very efficient 24-hour hotline of bc survivors...really invaluable during those sometimes long, hard nights in the beginning....Please PM me anytime.  I have a strong feeling that you are going to be okay!!!!!!!
Posts.Title: so lost..please help cupcake7 angie27

Posts.Content: Jul 22, 2012 02:10AM pennylane wrote: Hi Susan..Am up late and saw this...It seems like it's always summer when bc makes itself known...For me it has been nearly seven years since discovery...I have blocked out a lot, but do remember that my fear and sadness was brutally complete...Tranqs helped me a bit (valium)...but found a great deal of relief when I relented and started a program of anti-depressants (lexapro for me)...Are your Drs sure you are Stage 3 or is this still open til more tests are done?  Whatever stage it is, as you read the various threads here, you will learn of longtime survivors no matter what the stage.  The idea of chemo was very scarey to me, but there is an anti-nausea drug (emend) that really does its job...I never got sick to my stomach...just had very little appetite...Other women will tell you the same thing...This is one amazing support group and you will meet some very smart women who will help you thru just about every step of treatment...As for your husband...Yeah I have one of those...Oddly, just as I was about to divorce mine, I made the bc discovery, and he was quite kind and supportive thoughout my rough year...My theory on that is, they all get really crazy when they hit 40 and then just get crazier...although must say, yours is really taking it to new levels...penile implant?  whew!...I am a little sentimental so am still with mine...Perhaps yours will come thru for you too...the book is never closed on these long marriages...but they certainly lose importance when facing our one and only mortality....Anyway, Susan, hope you get some sleep tonite, and this will all be over sooner than you think...Hang in there...best wishes, P
Posts.Title: New and Terrified SusanHG123 lauta

Posts.Content: Aug 13, 2010 01:45AM pennylane wrote: Up late myself and noticed your post....Your lab is so lovely...and listen, with a 2cm tumor and no node involvement, I think you are probably somewhere between Stage 1 or 2a....Perhaps you are Grade 3 and that is the "3" you are seeing on your paperwork?  BC grades are often grade 3 as that is the nature of  the thing.  Congratulations on your clean margins and clean nodes and successful surgery...You sound very brave and I have a feeling you will breeze thru your treatments....Hang in...keep writing here...soon this will be a blurry memory and your life will be yours again....Best wishes, P
Posts.Title: Got results LuvMyLab JannyM

Posts.Content: Jan 4, 2011 03:30AM pennylane wrote: Hi Luca....Yes you are too young for this miserable thing, but that being said, it is your life, your show, and you have to do what you have to do.  Five years ago I put off what I had to do because my sister-in-law had just been dx....Thought I had a "sympathy lump"  Yeah pretty crazy what denial will make you think.  I was lucky to still be early stage knock on wood.  I think there is a really good chance that your hunch is right and that you are fine right now...but....please be vigilant, and get everything done that will bring this thing to a happy and complete conclusion.  Keep writing here for encouragement.  You can do this!!!! Best wishes, P
Posts.Title: Too scared to get biopsy... Luca33 Luca33

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2008 04:00AM pennylane wrote: what a beautiful person in every way...I will always remember Joanne and the story of her life.  She was so kind to me and so many, many others.  Just so heartbreaking...May she rest in peace now.
Posts.Title: Fare Thee Well Love.... joannes_brother lewisfamily503

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2008 12:13AM pennylane wrote: So sorry you are going though this at such a ridiculously young age.  Please try not to get too far ahead of yourself with this miserable thing.  I like the fact that the radiologist just saw a slight abnormality.  In my case and in so many others, they usually know just by looking the first time when something is grossly wrong.  So, there is a lot of hope on your side..sounds like much more than 50-50 in your favor.  Try to focus on that for the next few days.  Please try to get some tranquilizers to help you get through this...be kind to yourself....Oh, and I thought the tumor I felt was huge, but in the end was 1.7cm, not nearly as enormous as what I was expecting.  I have a strong feeling you are going to be okay!  Please hang in...we are all hoping and praying you will be fine and that this will soon just be a shadowy memory in your young life.....
Posts.Title: Waiting for biopsy for 2 inch tumor cestovatela Beth1128

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2009 03:23AM pennylane wrote: Hi K...I am triple neg and 4-years out....I have read a lot about triple neg in the past 4-years and have met many, many long-term triple neg survivors.   It is usually a high-grade bc and therefore often gets this nasty rep.  Yet all I know for sure about triple neg is that there is no targeted treatment and that is the reason that it is always treated with chemo...and it is generally thought to really respond to chemo as opposed to hormone positve bc.  Triple neg also is thought to have fewer cases of recurrance after 3-5 years out....so it is not all bad news.  It is just a little harder to believe in the beginning because recurrance rates are a little higher the first couple of years....I am so happy your mom has no node involvement...that is such a wonderful prognostic indicator...Stay on these boards during treatment...the women here are smart and supportive....Best wishes, P
Posts.Title: Triple Negative IDC and radiation? kenziezmommie thenewme

Posts.Content: Jul 8, 2008 01:32AM pennylane wrote: What wonderful news.  A few years from now this will just be one more memory of your 26th summer.  Yes, do get that removed and then go out to the beach for a nice long swim.  You have made a lot of women here very happy!!!! Wishing you all the best, P
Posts.Title: Waiting for biopsy for 2 inch tumor cestovatela Beth1128

Posts.Content: Sep 24, 2015 05:34PM pennylane wrote: Hi Ltam, I am ten-years out, and yes, I had crazy diffuse subcentimeter nodules all over both lungs...I believe mine were discovered after rads....I was so scared and dr. did not calm me down...Had to come here to get real story...So many ladies came on board to tell me they had similar experience and it is quite common to have benign stuff show up on scans of lungs...It is the price of being an adult in an unclean world...and certainly pneumonia is prime source of odd little nodules...and I had just gotten over pneumonia when I was scanned...You may be asked to come back for additional scans every 6-months for a year or two...Your Dr may want to do a PET but You are stage 1...and that is a good indication that this thing is just residue of an old illness...I just know you will be fine! Best wishes....
Posts.Title: Cat Scan found lung nodule...nervous Ltam16 Hopeful82014

Posts.Content: Apr 17, 2008 01:51AM pennylane wrote: Hi brenda, Let's see, back in July 2006 they found numerous sub-centimeter spots in my lungs...This was just a couple of months after rads and I was just nuts with fear, but have been scanned every 6-months since then, and everything is still stable.  As you seem to have guessed, you really do learn how to live between scans without much worrying.  Early on I did have a Pet scan and  was so pleased when nothing lit up....however, I was cautioned that the nodules were very tiny and therefore to still keep one eye open....I have a strong hunch that you are  just fine....and please have a little faith, as you can see sometimes we do get lucky too!   Best wishes, p
Posts.Title: Chest X Ray - Shadow on Lung esserbre esserbre

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2009 03:26AM pennylane wrote: Sister Peace, Oh boy, I had a long day like that back in 2005.  Somehow, those impersonal subway rides are so fitting after a day of testing and waiting and then more testing.  wow, what a gray day it was here in nyc....so meloncholy.  Anyway I am so glad you got this hard day of testing done....Oddly, 3 plus years later, that first day stands out in my mind as one of the hardest things I had to do......Whatever happens, (and I pray it's nothing)...You can do this!....Best wishes, P

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2012 05:16AM pennylane wrote: Dr Kimberly Van Zee was my surgeon at MSK in NYC....She really knows her stuff and always felt having her on my side during my bc experience was a huge piece of luck....
Posts.Title: NY Breast Surgeons dventi ashla

Posts.Content: May 12, 2008 06:46AM pennylane wrote: Hi Mary, Just my opinion, but I think the pharmacist is wrong about holding off on taking the emend.  I fear you will get really nausious if you do that....please take that drug as instructed, and by that I mean those first couple of days after the chemo....  As for the dizzyness that happens on days 4, 5, etc....Would you consider getting a perscription for valium?  It's kind of an old tranquilizer but kind of a friendly one, in that there are few side effects and for me, has worked wonders for dizzy spells I have had in the past.  Other things I have used included strong peppermint tea and "Ginger Wonder", which is the brand name of a strong ginger extract.  And don't forget the obvious....always lower your head between your legs as soon as the dizzyness starts...the blood rush usually stops it in a few minutes.  Well, I guess those are a few of my tricks, for what it's worth....oh, and just remember...dizzy spells do end sooner than you may think now.  Best wishes to you for a speedy and easy treatment from now on.....Yours truly,P
Posts.Title: anti-nausea drugs mary6204 leaf

Posts.Content: Dec 26, 2010 04:34AM pennylane wrote:  Hi Lovingmother, Just thought I would touch base with you.  This is the lonliest, hardest time you will have in your bc journey.  The beginning is so brutal...you have been thrown into a strange, scarey place and have to scramble to get information on a topic that we all hoped we would never have to learn about in this lifetime.  I do remember asking my surgeon what she would do re lumpectomy vs. mx...She practices at MSK and is a strong believer in lumpectomy plus rads whenever possible.  She also stressed it is a very personal decision and that many women only feel safe with mx...I understand this but in retrospect greatly appreciated the fairly simple lumpectomy and quick healing time.  Survival stats are supposed to be the same as long as you get clear margins with the surgery.  I hope you have considered seeing a therapist so that you can get some tranqs and more importantly anti-depressants.  Many of the women on these boards agree that this is not the time to be a big shot and I remember kicking myself for not taking Lexapro sooner.  I hated the tears and within one week I felt so much more control of my emotions.  I am 5-years out now, and I want you to be assured that once treatment starts things will move much quicker and you will get your life back and be happy again...If you skip to the "moving on" thread you will read of women who are many years out kidding around, talking about many things not just bc...Its gonna be okay...Best wishes, P
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed :( loving_mother nwest125

Posts.Content: Apr 16, 2012 05:55PM pennylane wrote: So sorry you find yourself here...I remember well the utter confusion and need for information in the beginning.  But if You are hearing that you are early stage that is great news...I assure you that your Dr is not telling you that to make you feel better...the medical establishment is brutally honest these days....The Dr you are meeting with next is probably going to be your surgeon who will send you for an MRI so that they can have a better idea of surgery options...They probably will try to take a peek to see if anything untowards shows up re lymph involvement...Chances are they are not seeing much to indicate that now as they are using the all important "early" to describe your situation...If lumpectomy is an option...then your surgeon will detail your surgery choices as some women, for their own reasons, still prefer MX....At the time of surgery they do a sentinal node biopsy to make sure there is no node involvement under your arm....6-years ago when I went thru this, surgery usually came first, It seems today they will often go with chemo first, or perhaps more sophisticated testing before anything is done!  But bc treatment these days is usually following a well-researched pattern...and most importantly..you have found this website...Stay here and read and post often...The women here really understand and will help you to advocate for yourself....Best wishes...P
Posts.Title: Just diagnosed, big pile of unknown Lifeonitsside debbie6122

Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2009 05:08AM pennylane wrote: Olive I am so sorry this has happened to you....Nothing in our lives prepares us for this moment.  I hated the crying too...it seemed relentless....I finally decided to get some anti-depressants (lexapro) and within a week my emotions were under control again....I also would take the occasional valium...These things are not excessive and seem to help a lot of us in the beginning.  Sounds like you have a very small amount of bc...these things are so treatable these days and your prognosis is probably excellent...It was exactly 4-years ago that I was dx and am now back in my life and the tears stopped many years ago....It is good that your surgeon is moving right along...Most of us felt things moved too slow in the beginning....Here is a 24-hour tel # I used  years ago: 1-800-221-2141...these are breast cancer survivors and someone always picks up...they used to be called Y-Me, perhaps the name of the group has changed, but I know the tel # is the same....Listen...you are going to be fine...Have a little faith and keep reaching out to other survivors...we will get you through this....Best wishes,P
Posts.Title: So Scared oliveoile terrij152

Posts.Content: Jan 27, 2009 03:32AM pennylane wrote: A beautiful human....her journey somehow cut to the core of all of us here...I will always remember her story.......
Posts.Title: Alaska Deb is our newest Angel. Traci-----TripNeg 4753

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2010 07:55AM pennylane wrote: Hi Gofish...My cousin did the oncotype test, and as expected her score was not low.  Today she just finished her fourth round of AC and in two weeks will start the T part of the treatment.  She did great during these first four rounds (knock on wood) and I'm hoping the next four will be easy on her.  Four years ago I only did the 4 rounds of AC and had a miserable time so I'm glad someone in our family is doing this bc thing smart and cool and tough.  Sounds like you will have a difficult time making this chemo decision....some very conflicting information in your stats....Yet please remember you are early stage and so things should work out for you no matter what you decide.  And wow, that oncotype "zero" sure is encouraging for your prognosis...I guess at this point it is time to ask several of your Dr's what they would do if they were in your shoes....Stay strong and sure...Wishing you all the best, P.
Posts.Title: Stage 2a needs help with chemo decision pennylane DiDel

Posts.Content: pennylane wrote: Hi I am 4-years out and now am seeking help for my cousin.  She has just finished surgery and we are all so confused with the chemos being offered now just 4 short years later.  (I only had the A&C)...My cousin is Stage 2a, hormone+, her2-, grade 3, a small 11mm tumor, and yet 2 lymph nodes involved.  She has gone to several Drs and has heard about TAC, just T&C, and even some clinical trials...She is still pre-menopausal and is very vibrant and physically fit.  We would so appreciate any input on this and perhaps you can share how you made your final decision...Thank you all so much....P Dx 8/1/2005, IDC, 1cm, Stage IA, Grade 3, 0/11 nodes, ER-/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: mena got her wings... celia088 Irina

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2014 04:29AM pennylane wrote: Hi Ddkath...I'm so sorry to hear you are having such a rough time getting through the first part of this process.  My cousin who was dx several years after me had a very similar situation...Tumor size was only 11mm, but during first surgery they did not get enough clearance on one margin and also to her dismay they found 2-lymph nodes affected...She did go back for a little surgery to have the margin cleared...and by the way this was lumpectomy....She opted for 8 rounds of chemo (4 of the ac followed by 4 taxanes)...A few months later she married her new boyfriend (October 10th 2010)....She is doing great today on hormone therapy...no side effects and she looks more beautiful than ever...So anyway, small tumor and 2-nodes is considered Stage 2a....which is early stage!  I hope you can  concentrate on positives..you just had an awful blow...try to read all the success stories of women with the same dx as yourself...Oh and if you do chemo, remember to get  emend for nausea...It is a miracle medicine...I took it and nver even came close to being sick to my stomach...Just never had much of an appetite...no big deal...And while on the topic of pills, I did take first valium and then lexapro to get rid of the anxiety and depression...My only regret was not taking them sooner!   Okay so a major bump in the road for you, but I bet anything, there will be no more unpleasant surprises...and very soon it will just be a waiting game till this whole thing is over...sending you best wishes...P
Posts.Title: Freaked out and have no idea where to start Ddkath70 Holeinone

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2014 02:42AM pennylane wrote: Hi Dkath...Havent been here in a while and your post popped out at me...I had the same horrific experience when I was first seeking diagnosis...Brutal remarks by radiologist...left no doubt in my mind...I felt so doomed I was lucky I somehow made it home without getting run over by a truck or something.  I dont know why these people arent trained to keep their mouths shut until  a biopsy is done...That being said, I have been out now for 8 1/2 years and I hope that number will give you hope that things will work out for you too...Initially they thought the mass I had was 2 cm and it turned out to be 1.7 cm...Maybe what you have is smaller too...And  maybe what you have is benign....But if you have to go thru treatment I want you to know there is safety in numbers...The women here will get you thru it all and really know their stuff...and have enough sense and heart to not sucker punch you like that nasty piece of work that calls herself a doctor....Try and get a few tranqs of some sort to get you thru the next few weeks...A lot of us here need a little help to get thru this...But wait...there is still hope it is nothing...Hang in there Dkath...
Posts.Title: Freaked out and have no idea where to start Ddkath70 Holeinone
